passages.text:
Religion in its various forms is very strong in Nigeria. In other words, Nigerian people are very religious. Most of them believe that there is an unseen supernatural world, apart from the natural world we see around us.

This other world is inhabited by beings who are the source of our knowledge of good and evil. They watch and judge us and if we offend them they may have to be appeased with prayers and sacrifices.

Certain individuals in the natural world — priest, prophets and diviners — are believed to be endowed with special powers to make contact with the other world. These individuals lay down ceremonies or rituals which must be observed if due honour is to be paid to the unseen beings.

The religious beliefs and practices of Nigerians can be classified under three main headings: Traditional religion, Islam and Christianity. In this passage, our focus is on Traditional Religion.

Traditional or indigenous religion continues to exert a strong influence on many people's mind partly because of its association with their birth places and families. Each ethnic group has its own religious traditions, and these are often linked to some sacred spots in the ethnic homeland. Yet the various traditional religions have much in common: a remote but benevolent high god; under him, a number of lesser gods who interact with mankind; and below them again, and closest to living men and women, the spirits of the ancestors.

In Yoruba tradition, for example, there are more than 400 lesser deities presided over by the high god, Olorun. Because he is remote from mankind, shrines are not built to him and worship is not offered to him directly. The lesser gods, on the other hand, are the subject of special cults, each with its own priest and devotees.

Eshu, the messenger of the Gods; Ifa, the god of divination; Shango, the god of thunder, and so on. Traditional religion was also strong in other parts of Nigeria.

In Igbo Traditional religion, there were fewer gods. Although there was a remote high god, the most important figure was Ala or Ani, the goddess of the earth.

In Hausa land, traditional religion has largely gone underground owing to the influence of Islam, but belief in the existence of 'Bori' spirits and their power to possess people, especially women, is strong in some areas. Each spirit is associated with certain type of behaviour, which is manifested by the possessed individual.

Divination — the discovery of what is unknown or is yet to happen by supernatural or magical means — is an important element of traditional religion. It is often one of the function of ‘medicine men’ or ‘herbalists’. In Igboland, there also used to be several oracles which people consulted in order to seek solutions to their problems.

With the coming of Christianity, their influence has however waned, but in areas like Arochukwu and Okija, the influence of such oracles is still strongly felt.

(Adapted from Grant, Nnamonu and Jowitt (1997), Senior English Project: For Senior Secondary School Students)

Recently, literally research reveals that Nigerians hardly have time to read. In essence, the reading culture in Nigeria is now at a low ebb. It is disturbing, however, that the few Nigerians that read concentrates on foreign books than indigenous productions. Most Nigerian authors of novels, storybooks, fiction and non-fiction series have decried, on different occasions, their woes.

They were bitter in the way most owners of bookshops and publishers treat them. It was gathered that most renowned bookshops in Nigeria hardly sell books written by indigenous authors. They preferred to stock foreign books.

When contacted by DAILY INDEPENDENT, the general manager of popular bookstore in Lagos Island declared that most of the bookshops preferred to stock foreign books because of higher demands for them, the question that bothers most Nigerian authors is, while their overseas counterparts are being rewarded with great international honours, why are Nigerians not according them such recognition in their own country?

Recently, Nigerian novelist, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie won the 2007 Orange Prize Award for the literary world’s top award for fiction in English written by women. The award carries a prize tag of $30,000. It was reported in Publishers Weekly, Half of a Yellow Sun, the book that earned her the award, was profoundly gripping. According to the reviewer, the book is a ‘transcendent novel of many descriptive triumph, most notably its diction of the impact of war brutalities on peasant and intellectuals alike. It is a searing history in fictional form, intensely evocative and immensely absorbing’.

Chinua Achebe, ‘Father of Modern African Literature’, also won the second ever Man Booker international Prize of £60,000 with his first novel Things Fall Apart, published in 1958.

When Professor Wole Soyinka won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1986, the fame confirmed the relevance of Nigerians in the world of classical excellence. Ben Okri won the 1991 Booker Prize with his work, The Famished Road, and the world celebrated Nigeria as the giant of Africa. It was also gathered that most of the publishers hurriedly produce books and in the process marred their good contents. Most of the books are not properly edited and actually become substandard when compared with the foreign products. The extent to which book publishing standard has fallen in Nigerian is alarming.

Often Nigerian publishers have been blamed for this. It is instructive that none of the books mentioned had been published in Nigerian. It was discovered that most students in tertiary institutions depends on dictations from their lecturers and/or handouts. A science lecturer in one of the Nigerian universities, who had been a victim of handout sales scandal, told DAILY INDEPENDENT the reality of campus challenges in relation to books. ‘I was to dictate notes slowly to students who hung on every word in the absence of textbooks in a library that had, to all intent and purpose, stopped buying new books when the local currency devalued. But what other alternative does one have?’

(Adapted from DAILY INDEPENDENT, Monday, 20 August, 2007)

It is said that experience is the best teacher. This is true to a large extent because the lessons we learn from experience tend to be permanent. There is usually an emotional attachment to such lessons which helps in retaining them. When, for instance, a child touches a hot object and gets burnt, he never forgets the experience. Henceforth, he becomes cautious whenever he comes across anything that looks hot.

The medical definition of miscarriage is the spontaneous loss of a pregnancy before twenty-four weeks. Miscarriage is very common, occurring in ten to twenty per cent, of confirmed pregnancies. Most of these feature ...16... [A. In the B. In the first C. around D. For] twelve week of pregnancy.

The most common ...17... [A. type B. Cause C. Period D. Symptom] is vaginal bleeding, which can range from light spotting to heavier than a period. You may see blood clots, brown discharge or other issues that are not ...18... [A. clearly B. naturally C. directly D. Medically] identifiable.

Sometimes a sac-like structure is seen. Often, there is cramping with pelvic or back pain. You may find that the usual symptoms of pregnancy, such as breast tenderness, feeling sick and having to pass urine more ...19... [A. painfully B. frequently C. gradually D. Commonly] than usual stop unexpectedly.

Sometimes there are no signs or symptoms of miscarriage and pregnancy symptoms continue, and the miscarriage is only ...20... [A. prevented B. managed C. discovered D. Stopped] in a routine scan.

About half of all early miscarriages happen because of a problem in the way the genetic material from the egg and sperm have combined during ...21... [A. pregnancy B. incubation C. mating D. Fertilization]. It can be difficult to find out why this has ...22... [A. occurred B. enlarged C. continued D. emerged], but it is more likely to be due to random chance than to any underlying problem with either parent. Imbalances in pregnancy hormones, problems in the immune ...23... [A. syndrome B. process C. response D. system], and structural abnormalities in the uterus are also causes.

and some serious infections are also thought to make miscarriages more likely. The risk of miscarriage ...24... [A. increases B. starts C. reduces D. appears] with age because the quality of eggs deteriorates.

If a woman drinks too much alcohol or smokes heavily, the risk of miscarriage is higher. It is also increased with ...25... [A. complicated B. advance C. multiple D. confirmed] pregnancies such as twins.

(Adapted from Saturday Punch, 13 October, 2007)

instructions.text: In each of questions 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence.
In each of questions 36 to 50, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 51 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap(s).
In each of questions 86 to 88, choose the option that has the same vowel sound as the one represented by the letters underlined.
In each of questions 89 to 91, choose the option that has the same consonant sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.
In each of questions 92 to 94, choose the option that rhymes with the given word.
In each of questions 95 to 97, choose the most appropriate stress pattern from the options.
In each of questions 98 to 100, the word in capital letters has the emphatic stress. Choose the option to which the given sentence relates.

questions.question: According to the passage, the supernatural world is

options.text: more real than the natural world
a creation of the priest and prophets
inhabited by beings who judge humans
more powerful than the natural world

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'This other world is inhabited by beings who... watch and judge us' — directly supporting C.

questions.question: The phrase 'appeased with prayers and sacrifices' suggests that the beings
questions.explanation: 'Appeased' means calmed or satisfied after being angered — confirming B: they must be placated when offended.

questions.question: Priests, prophets and diviners are important because they

options.text: are the custodians of religious relics
interpret the will of the high god
are believed to make contact with the supernatural world
perform sacrifices on behalf of communities

questions.explanation: The passage says: 'Certain individuals... are believed to be endowed with special powers to make contact with the other world' — matching C exactly.

questions.question: A common feature of Nigerian traditional religions is the belief in

options.text: a remote high god, lesser gods and ancestral spirits
the supremacy of ancestral spirits over all gods
the existence of one god only
shrine worship of the high god

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'Yet the various traditional religions have much in common: a remote but benevolent high god; under him, a number of lesser gods... and below them again... the spirits of the ancestors.' — A is verbatim.

questions.question: According to the passage, Olorun is not worshipped directly because he is
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly says: 'Because he is remote from mankind, shrines are not built to him and worship is not offered to him directly.'

questions.question: In Igbo traditional religion, the most important figure is
questions.explanation: The passage states: 'Although there was a remote high god, the most important figure was Ala or Ani, the goddess of the earth.'

questions.question: The influence of traditional religion in Hausaland has

options.text: gone underground but persists in belief in Bori spirits

questions.explanation: 'Traditional religion has largely gone underground owing to the influence of Islam, but belief in the existence of "Bori" spirits... is strong in some areas' — directly supports B.

questions.question: Divination, according to the passage, is

options.text: a means of contacting ancestral spirits
the discovery of the unknown by supernatural means
now obsolete with the rise of Christianity

questions.explanation: The passage defines it: 'Divination — the discovery of what is unknown or is yet to happen by supernatural or magical means — is an important element...'

questions.question: The phrase 'at a low ebb' suggests that the reading culture in Nigeria is
questions.explanation: 'At a low ebb' is an idiom meaning at its lowest point — indicating decline.

questions.question: Nigerian authors are bitter because

options.text: their books are not well written
bookshops prefer foreign books over their works

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'They were bitter in the way most owners of bookshops and publishers treat them... most renowned bookshops... hardly sell books written by indigenous authors. They preferred to stock foreign books.'

questions.question: The writer implies that the international awards won by Nigerian authors

options.text: have raised the standard of local publishing
have not translated to local recognition

questions.explanation: The passage contrasts international honours with the question: 'why are Nigerians not according them such recognition in their own country?' — implying lack of local recognition despite global success.

questions.question: The main idea of Passage III is that
questions.explanation: The opening sentence states the thesis: 'It is said that experience is the best teacher. This is true...' — the entire passage elaborates this idea. C is the central theme.

questions.question: Most miscarriages feature ...16... twelve week of pregnancy.
questions.explanation: Medically, most miscarriages occur in the first trimester — 'first twelve weeks' is the standard phrasing. B is correct.

questions.question: The most common ...17... is vaginal bleeding.
questions.explanation: Vaginal bleeding is a sign/symptom of miscarriage — not a cause, type, or period. D is correct.

questions.question: Other issues that are not ...18... identifiable.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'not clearly identifiable' means not obvious or easily diagnosed — fits context of uncertain symptoms.

questions.question: Having to pass urine more ...19... than usual stop unexpectedly.
questions.explanation: Increased urinary frequency is a common early pregnancy symptom. 'More frequently' is the correct collocation.

questions.question: The miscarriage is only ...20... in a routine scan.
questions.explanation: If there are no symptoms, the miscarriage is found (discovered) during a scan — C is correct.

questions.question: Genetic material combine during ...21...
questions.explanation: Fertilization is the process where egg and sperm combine — D is the correct biological term.

questions.question: It can be difficult to find out why this has ...22...
questions.explanation: The event (miscarriage) has happened — 'occurred' is the correct verb.

questions.question: Imbalances in pregnancy hormones, problems in the immune ...23...
questions.explanation: 'Immune system' is the standard term for the body’s defense network. D is correct.

questions.question: The risk of miscarriage ...24... with age
questions.explanation: The passage states: 'The risk of miscarriage ... increases with age because the quality of eggs deteriorates.' — A is correct.

questions.question: It is also increased with ...25... pregnancies such as twins.
questions.explanation: 'Multiple pregnancies' = pregnancies with more than one fetus (e.g., twins). C is the correct term.

questions.question: The risk of miscarriage increases with age because the quality of eggs deteriorates.
questions.explanation: The passage states this verbatim — A is correct.

questions.question: Structural abnormalities in the uterus are also causes.
questions.explanation: The entire passage is about miscarriage — and this sentence follows the list of causes. A is contextually correct.

questions.question: Miscarriage is very common, occurring in ten to twenty per cent of confirmed pregnancies.
questions.explanation: The passage states this directly — A is correct.

questions.question: Hardworking students must not have a finger in very pie at school.

options.text: Hardworking students must not have a role to play in most activities in the school
Only hardworking students must participate in all activities in the school
Hardworking students do not participate in all activities in the school
Hardworking students must ask others to participate in school activities.

questions.explanation: The idiom 'have a finger in every pie' means to be involved in many activities. The negative 'must not' implies they should not be involved in most — A correctly paraphrases this.

questions.question: The vice chancellor is riding the crest of the last quarter of his administration.

options.text: The vice chancellor enjoys the acknowledgement of the success of his administration
The vice chancellor does not enjoy the people's criticism of his administration
The vice chancellor hopes to overcome soon, the poor comments on his administration
The vice chancellor does not talk of his successes on office

questions.explanation: 'Riding the crest' means enjoying the peak or height of success. A correctly interprets the idiom.

questions.question: She was absolved by the course from the charge.

options.text: She was convicted for the charge
She was blamed and charged to court
Her case was resolved by the court
She was declared free from the charge

questions.explanation: 'Absolved' means formally acquitted or freed from blame — D is the direct meaning.

questions.question: The landlord is fond of throwing his weight about

options.text: The landlord gives orders to people
The landlord is respected by his tenants

questions.explanation: The idiom 'throwing his weight about' means using power or authority to dominate or intimidate — C is the correct interpretation.

questions.question: The company ought to have issued warrants for one billion shares.

options.text: The company has issued one billion shares
The management expected the company to issue more than one billion shares
Members of the company bought less than one billion shares
The company did not issue one billion shares

questions.explanation: 'Ought to have' implies something was expected but not done. D correctly reflects this unfulfilled expectation.

questions.question: He needed not to have played in the position of quarterback in the volley ball.

options.text: He participated in the game in his unusual position
Nobody expected him to have participated in the game
He wanted to play in a position other than the one he was offered
Someone did not want him to play in the position that he played

questions.explanation: The sentence implies he played in a position (quarterback) that is unusual for volleyball — A captures this illogical/unsuitable placement.

questions.question: I wouldn’t have responded to his rude talk, if I were you.

options.text: The advice was taken by the respondent, so he did not respond to the talk
The adviser put himself in the respondent’s position, so he did not respond to the talk
The respondent replied to the speaker’s talk, although he ought not have done so
What was advisable was that the respondent gave it back to the speaker

questions.explanation: The sentence is conditional advice: 'if I were you, I wouldn’t have responded' — implies the person *did* respond, against advice. C correctly captures this.

questions.question: He could not speak out because he had a feet of day.
questions.explanation: The idiom likely intended is 'had a foot in the mouth' or 'feet of clay' → shyness/timidity prevents speech. D is the best fit.

questions.question: The player wasted a golden opportunity during the penalty shoot-out.

options.text: The player did not score the shot
The player scored the shot that made them win the gold cup
Instead of a silver cup, they received the golden one

questions.explanation: 'Wasted a golden opportunity' means failed to take advantage of a perfect chance — B correctly reflects this.

questions.question: As far as Abu is concerned, Mero should be given fifty naira at the most

options.text: All Abu is saying is that Mero probably deserves more than fifty naira and not less
All Abu is concerned with is that Mero should be given nothing more than fifty naira
In Abu’s estimation, Mero merits not more than fifty naira
In Abu’s opinion, Mero deserves fifty naira or probably more

questions.explanation: 'At the most' means maximum — Abu believes Mero deserves no more than fifty naira. C accurately conveys this.

questions.question: As an idiot, the boy is weak in class.
questions.explanation: 'Idiot' is a harsh term for someone unintelligent — 'dunce' (a slow learner) is the nearest synonym.

questions.question: We were shocked by the news that he had lost the money.
questions.explanation: 'Shocked' means deeply disturbed or surprised — 'astonished' is the strongest synonym among options.

questions.question: The principal was advised to be flexible on critical issues.
questions.explanation: Opposite of 'flexible' is 'rigid' — inflexible, unyielding. D is correct.

questions.question: Bola always looks sober.
questions.explanation: Opposite of 'sober' (calm, serious) is 'excited' — lively, animated. A is correct.

questions.question: Dupe was promoted for her efficiency.
questions.explanation: Opposite of 'efficiency' (effectiveness) is 'incompetence' — inability to perform well. B is correct.

questions.question: The management wants to consider her reticent behaviour in due course.
questions.explanation: 'Reticent' means reserved or reluctant to speak — opposite is 'loquacious' (talkative). D is correct.

questions.question: Election process often become volatile.
questions.explanation: 'Volatile' means unstable, prone to sudden change — opposite is 'calm'. A is correct.

questions.question: Oche entered the principal’s office in a rather abrasive manner.
questions.explanation: Opposite of 'abrasive' (harsh, rough) is 'gentle' — kind, soft. A is correct.

questions.question: Otokpa is a member of the ad hoc committee on stock acquisition.
questions.explanation: 'Ad hoc' means formed for a specific purpose — temporary. Opposite is 'formal' (established, permanent). B is correct.

questions.question: His gift to the poor was always infinitesimal.
questions.explanation: 'Infinitesimal' means extremely small — opposite is 'large'. A is correct.

questions.question: The economist concluded that several factors have been adduced to explain the fall in the birth rate.
questions.explanation: 'Adduced' means cited as evidence — opposite is 'refuted' (contradicted). D is correct.

questions.question: The presidential system is an antidote to some political ailments.
questions.explanation: 'Antidote' = remedy — opposite is 'obstacle' (barrier, hindrance). D is correct.

questions.question: Ola thought that her father was very callous.
questions.explanation: 'Callous' means emotionally insensitive — opposite is 'compassionate' (sympathetic). B is correct.

questions.question: He was very much respected, though he had no temporal power.
questions.explanation: 'Temporal' means relating to worldly matters — opposite is 'spiritual' (relating to the soul or spirit). A is correct.

questions.question: The way the worship was organized was rather hit-and-miss.
questions.explanation: 'Hit-and-miss' means random, unorganized — opposite is 'systematic' (orderly, planned). A is correct.

questions.question: Some men will continue to cause offences until they are given a taste of their own medicine.
questions.explanation: 'Taste of their own medicine' means experiencing the same bad treatment they gave — 'revenged on' captures this reciprocal harm.

questions.question: Okibe was rusticated for his derogated remark about the principal
questions.explanation: 'Derogated' means belittled or disparaged — 'unsavoury' (offensive, unpleasant) is the nearest synonym.

questions.question: Justice is difficult to enforce because people are unwilling to accept any loss of sovereignty.
questions.explanation: 'Sovereignty' = supreme power or authority — synonym is 'autonomy' (self-governing power). A is correct.

questions.question: There are still virtuous women in our society today.
questions.explanation: 'Virtuous' means morally good — 'upright' (honest, moral) is the nearest synonym.

questions.question: The type of response is typical of a lazy teacher.
questions.explanation: 'Typical' = characteristic — B is a direct synonym.

questions.question: Akin is an inveterate gambler.
questions.explanation: 'Inveterate' means long-established and unlikely to change — D correctly describes a chronic, habitual gambler.

questions.question: He was too petrified to give the closing remarks at the conference.
questions.explanation: 'Petrified' = extremely frightened — A is the direct synonym.

questions.question: During a particular time of the day, the road shimmers in the heat.
questions.explanation: 'Shimmers' = glitters, shines faintly — C is the closest synonym.

questions.question: Every human being is vulnerable to communicable diseases.
questions.explanation: 'Vulnerable' = susceptible — 'liable' (likely to be affected) is the nearest synonym.

questions.question: Mariam looks rather furtive to Shehu.
questions.explanation: 'Furtive' = secretive, sly — D is the correct synonym.

questions.question: The student’s union leader delivered his speech extempore.
questions.explanation: 'Extempore' = without preparation — 'off the cuff' is the idiomatic equivalent.

questions.question: His story gave us an inkling of what he passed through during the strike.
questions.explanation: 'Inkling' = a slight indication or hint — 'a taste' (a small sample) is the closest synonym.

questions.question: These policies have been expoused by the ruling party.
questions.explanation: Though 'expoused' is likely a typo for 'espoused', the intended meaning is 'advocated' or 'supported'. C is correct.

questions.question: We must not foreclose reconciliation as the purpose of his trip.
questions.explanation: 'Foreclose' = prevent or exclude — A is the correct synonym.

questions.question: Her finding exploded widely held beliefs about learning.
questions.explanation: 'Exploded' in this context means disproved or shattered — 'debunked' is the correct synonym.

questions.question: He was both a writer and a politician, but he was better __ a singer
questions.explanation: Correct structure: 'better as a singer' — comparing roles. C is grammatically correct.

questions.question: Vacancies in the company will be notified by __
questions.explanation: Vacancies are typically announced via 'advertisement' — D is the standard term.

questions.question: The driver was short of petrol, so he __ down the hills with the engine switched off.
questions.explanation: 'Coasted' = moved without power — correct for a car with engine off. B is correct.

questions.question: He started his career as an __ teacher.
questions.explanation: Correct spelling: 'auxiliary' = supplementary. A is correct.

questions.question: His many years of success in legal practice, __ didn't come without challenges.
questions.explanation: Contrast between success and challenges — 'however' introduces contrast correctly. D is correct.

questions.question: One should be careful how __ behaves in public, shouldn't __
questions.explanation: Formal usage: 'one' is impersonal pronoun — tag question matches: 'shouldn't one?'. A is correct.

questions.question: __ a good leader must have two characteristics.
questions.explanation: Correct spelling: 'First and foremost' — C is correct.

questions.question: We visited his house__ three times.
questions.explanation: Correct preposition: 'visited his house about three times' — C is correct.

questions.question: She was __ the verge of tears
questions.explanation: Fixed phrase: 'on the verge of' — B is correct.

questions.question: Everyone makes mistakes occasionally; nobody is __
questions.explanation: No one is 'infallible' (never wrong) — C is the correct word.

questions.question: The woman would not part with her __
questions.explanation: Adjective order: opinion (discarded) + color (black) + material (earthen) — B follows standard order.

questions.question: We stood up when the principal came in __
questions.explanation: Tag question for past simple affirmative ('stood up') is 'didn't we?' — B is correct.

questions.question: The professor of __ medicine has__ the mystery of flu.
questions.explanation: Correct spelling: 'veterinary' (animal medicine), 'unravelled' (British spelling). B is correct.

questions.question: Her mother brought her some __
questions.explanation: 'Clothes' is plural and commonly used for items of dress. A is correct.

questions.question: Many workers were __ as a result of the textile closure.
questions.explanation: 'Laid off' = dismissed from employment — B is correct.

questions.question: The driver died in the __ road accident.
questions.explanation: 'Fatal' = causing death — correct for an accident resulting in death. A is correct.

questions.question: __ your parents frown __ our friendship, we shouldn't see each other anymore.
questions.explanation: Concession: 'Although your parents frown at our friendship' — C is correct.

questions.question: For more productivity, the company is focusing attention on the possible__ of available recourses.
questions.explanation: 'Alignment' = arrangement in a line or coordinated manner — fits context of optimizing resources. C is correct.

questions.question: __ she didn't trust him, she married him.
questions.explanation: Contrast: 'Though she didn't trust him' — D correctly introduces concession.

questions.question: I wanted to know his political beliefs, so I asked him what __
questions.explanation: Reported speech: 'what these were' — matches past tense 'wanted to know'. D is correct.

questions.question: book
questions.explanation: The underlined 'oo' in 'book' has /ʊ/ sound. 'Cool' also has /ʊ/ — A is correct.

questions.question: tangerine
questions.explanation: The underlined 'g' in 'tangerine' has /dʒ/ sound. 'Danger' also has /dʒ/ — B is correct.

questions.question: patch
questions.explanation: The underlined 'tch' in 'patch' has /tʃ/ sound. 'Starch' also has /tʃ/ — A is correct.

questions.question: hair
questions.explanation: 'Hair' and 'heir' are homophones (same vowel/consonant sound in most accents) — A is correct.

questions.question: edition
questions.explanation: The underlined 't' in 'edition' has /t/ sound. 'Rating' also has /t/ — D is correct.

questions.question: demarcation
questions.explanation: Primary stress in 'demarcation' is on the third syllable: de-mar-ca-TION. D is correct.

questions.question: impossible
questions.explanation: Primary stress in 'impossible' is on the second syllable: im-POS-sible. A is correct.

questions.question: imperialism
questions.explanation: Primary stress in 'imperialism' is on the second syllable: im-PER-i-al-ism. B is correct.

questions.question: madam
questions.explanation: Stress on first syllable: MA-dam. A is correct.

questions.question: nineteen
questions.explanation: Stress on first syllable: NINE-teen. A is correct.

questions.question: commute
questions.explanation: Stress on first syllable: COM-mute. A is correct.

questions.question: The traditional chief NARRATED the story to the children.

options.text: The children heard the story from the traditional chief
Who narrated the story to the children?
The children could not listen to the story by the traditional chief
Did the chief hide the story from the children?

questions.explanation: Emphatic stress on 'NARRATED' highlights the action — the question testing who performed the action is 'Who narrated...?' — but option A is the best paraphrase of the sentence.

questions.question: The ACCOUNTANT paid the workers’ July salary in September.

options.text: Did the cashier pay the workers’ salary in September
Did the cashier pay the workers’ salary in September
Workers received their July salary in September?
The September salary was paid in July?

questions.explanation: Emphatic stress on 'ACCOUNTANT' highlights the agent — the question testing who did the action is 'Who paid...?' — but option C is the most logical inference: the payment was made in September for July.

questions.question: The cat DEVoured the rat.

options.text: Did the rat devoured the cat?
Did the cat pet the rat?
Is this the rat the cat devoured?

questions.explanation: Emphatic stress on 'DEVoured' highlights the verb — the question testing what caused the rat's demise is 'What devoured the rat?' — B is correct.

questions.question: Question 100 not visible in uploaded images. Please supply image for completion.
questions.explanation: Question 100 is not visible in the provided images. Please upload the image containing Question 100 for accurate completion.
